natural solution: In general, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ b & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a + b & 1 \end{pmatrix},\]so \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018} = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}_{\text{2018 matrices}} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (nat, nat) mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1,0], [n,1]]"
shows  "A 2018 = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1,0], [2018,1]]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ b & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a + b & 1 \end{pmatrix},\]so \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018} = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}_{\text{2018 matrices}} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]

assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1,0], [n,1]]"
shows  "A 2018 = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1,0], [2018,1]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a sequence of 2x2 matrices $A_n$, defined such that the nth matrix $A_n$ has its elements defined by the rows [1,0] and [n,1], find the 2018th matrix $A_{2018}$. The final answer is the 2x2 matrix with rows [1,0] and [2018,1].

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. A 0 (i,j) = (if j = 1 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j n. A (Suc n) (i,j) = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then n+1 else A n (i,j))"
shows  "A 2018 (2,1) = 2018"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ b & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a + b & 1 \end{pmatrix},\]so \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018} = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}_{\text{2018 matrices}} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. A 0 (i,j) = (if j = 1 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j n. A (Suc n) (i,j) = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then n+1 else A n (i,j))"
shows  "A 2018 (2,1) = 2018"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Consider a function $A$ that takes a natural number $n$ and a pair of natural numbers $(i,j)$ and returns a natural number. The function is defined as follows:

- For any $i$ and $j$, $A(0, (i,j))$ is $1$ if $j=1$ and $0$ otherwise.
- For any $i$, $j$ and $n$, $A(n+1, (i,j))$ is $0$ if $i=1$ and $j=2$, $n+1$ if $i=2$ and $j=1$, and $A(n, (i,j))$ otherwise.

What is the value of $A(2018, (2,1))$? The final answer is 2018.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "M 1 = matrix([[1,0],[1,1]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> M n = M (n-1) * matrix([[1,0],[1,1]])"
shows  "M 2018 = matrix([[1,0],[2018,1]])"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ b & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a + b & 1 \end{pmatrix},\]so \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018} = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}_{\text{2018 matrices}} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "M 1 = matrix([[1,0],[1,1]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> M n = M (n-1) * matrix([[1,0],[1,1]])"
shows  "M 2018 = matrix([[1,0],[2018,1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A sequence of 2x2 matrices $M$ is defined such that the first matrix $M(1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and for any natural number $n \geq 2$, the nth matrix $M(n)$ is the product of the $(n-1)$th matrix and the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. What is the 2018th matrix in this sequence? The final answer is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

theorem
fixes M :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[1,0],[1,1]])"
and h1 : "M powr 2018 = matrix([[1,0],[2018,1]])"

 *)

fixes M :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[1,0],[1,1]])"
and h1 : "M powr 2018 = matrix([[1,0],[2018,1]])"
shows  "M powr 2018 = matrix([[1,0],[2018,1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix M with elements [[1,0],[1,1]], find the 2018th power of this matrix. The final answer is a matrix with elements [[1,0],[2018,1]].

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, 0], [n, 1]]"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. A (n + 1) = A n * A 1"
shows  "A 2018 = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, 0], [2018, 1]]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ b & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a + b & 1 \end{pmatrix},\]so \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018} = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}_{\text{2018 matrices}} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, 0], [n, 1]]"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. A (n + 1) = A n * A 1"
shows  "A 2018 = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, 0], [2018, 1]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a sequence of 2x2 matrices $A(n)$, where each matrix $A(n)$ has the rows [1,0] and [n,1]. If each matrix $A(n + 1)$ in the sequence is the product of the $n^{th}$ matrix and the first matrix $A(1)$, what is the matrix $A(2018)$? The final answer is the 2x2 matrix with rows [1,0] and [2018,1].

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat mat"
assumes h0 : "A = (\<lambda>n. mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then n else 0))"
shows  "A 2018 = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 2018 else 0)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ b & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a + b & 1 \end{pmatrix},\]so \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2018} = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}_{\text{2018 matrices}} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2018 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat mat"
assumes h0 : "A = (\<lambda>n. mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then n else 0))"
shows  "A 2018 = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 2018 else 0)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a function $A$ that generates a 2 by 2 matrix. For each natural number $n$, the matrix has 1 in the first row first column and second row second column, $n$ in the second row first column, and 0 in the rest. What is the matrix when $n=2018$? The final answer is a 2 by 2 matrix with 1 in the first row first column and second row second column, 2018 in the second row first column, and 0 in the remaining cell.
